prior_works.title: Ab initio solution of the many-electron Schrödinger equation with deep neural networks
prior_works.authors: David Pfau, James S. Spencer, Alexander G. de G. Matthews, W. M. C. Foulkes
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced FermiNet, demonstrating neural backflow with Slater determinants for continuum electrons; Neural Pfaffians directly builds on this paradigm but replaces determinant antisymmetry with Pfaffians to remove spin-structure constraints and enable a more general, learnable antisymmetric form.

prior_works.title: Deep neural network solution of the electronic Schrödinger equation
prior_works.authors: Jan Hermann, Zeno Schätzle, Frank Noé
prior_works.role: Alternative neural ansatz (PauliNet) highlighting reliance on orbital selection
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed competitive neural VMC using Slater–Jastrow forms tied to hand-crafted/externally computed orbitals; Neural Pfaffians explicitly overcomes this bottleneck by using a fully learnable Pfaffian ansatz that avoids discrete orbital selection while preserving antisymmetry.

prior_works.title: Pfaffian pairing wave functions in electronic-structure quantum Monte Carlo methods
prior_works.authors: K. Bajdich, L. Mitas, L. K. Wagner, K. E. Schmidt
prior_works.role: Mathematical and practical foundation for Pfaffian antisymmetric wavefunctions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established Pfaffians as a powerful generalization of Slater determinants capable of treating arbitrary spin configurations and pairing; Neural Pfaffians imports this Pfaffian structure into a modern, fully learnable neural architecture for transferable molecular modeling.

prior_works.title: Inhomogeneous backflow transformations in quantum Monte Carlo calculations
prior_works.authors: P. López Ríos, A. Ma, N. D. Drummond, M. D. Towler, R. J. Needs
prior_works.role: Core variational mechanism (backflow) later neuralized in FermiNet/PauliNet
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Backflow provided a route to improve nodal surfaces within antisymmetric ansätze; Neural Pfaffians leverages the idea of learnable coordinate transformations but pairs it with a Pfaffian layer to enforce antisymmetry without spin-separation constraints.

prior_works.title: Geminal wave functions with Jastrow correlation: A realistic description of electron correlation in molecules
prior_works.authors: M. Casula, C. Attaccalite, S. Sorella
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that antisymmetrized geminal (pairing) forms yield compact, transferable molecular wavefunctions; Neural Pfaffians can be viewed as a neural, overparameterized evolution of geminal/pairing ideas that captures general spin patterns via Pfaffians.

prior_works.title: Solving the quantum many-body problem with artificial neural networks
prior_works.role: Foundational concept of neural quantum states (NQS)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established neural networks as variational wavefunctions; Neural Pfaffians extends this NQS philosophy to continuum fermions with a Pfaffian-based antisymmetric architecture designed for cross-system generalization.

synthesis_narrative:
Neural Pfaffians sits at the intersection of two lines of progress: neural variational wavefunctions for continuum electrons and pairing-based antisymmetric ansätze from quantum Monte Carlo. FermiNet (Pfau et al., 2020) and PauliNet (Hermann et al., 2020) proved that deep networks with backflow-like transformations and Slater determinants can achieve chemical accuracy, but they typically train per-system and depend on spin-partitioned determinants and orbital choices, limiting transfer across molecules and spin sectors. The backflow literature (López Ríos et al., 2006) provided the variational mechanism that these neural methods adopted to improve nodal surfaces, while Carleo and Troyer (2017) established the general viability of neural quantum states.

On the antisymmetry front, the QMC community showed that pairing forms—AGP/JAGP (Casula et al., 2004)—and their generalization to Pfaffians (Bajdich et al., 2008) offer a compact, flexible representation that naturally accommodates arbitrary spin configurations and strong correlation beyond single-determinant Slater forms. Neural Pfaffians directly fuses these insights: it replaces determinant-based antisymmetry with a fully learnable Pfaffian layer, retaining the expressive, learnable coordinate transformations of neural VMC while eliminating non-learnable, discrete orbital selection and spin-factorization constraints. This Pfaffian-based architecture is overparameterized and suitable for amortization across molecular geometries and compositions, addressing the core limitation identified by determinant-based neural wavefunctions. In short, Neural Pfaffians operationalizes the established advantages of Pfaffian/pairing ansätze within the modern NQS framework to deliver a transferable, end-to-end learnable antisymmetric wavefunction across diverse many-electron systems.
